sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Multicentric Castleman's disease, In patients known to be HIV-negative and human herpesvirus-8-negative: initial, consider delay of treatment, but do not reduce dose, for absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 1 x 10(9)/L, platelet count less than 75 x 10(9)/L, Hb 17 g/dL or greater
  • Multicentric Castleman's disease, In patients known to be HIV-negative and human herpesvirus-8-negative: 11 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour every 3 weeks until treatment failure; consider delay of retreatment, but do not reduce dose, for ANC less than 1 x 10(9)/L, platelet count less than 50 x 10(9)/L, Hb 17 g/dL or greater

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (CrCl 25 mL/min or greater): no initial dose adjustment necessary
  • hepatic impairment (mild to moderate; Child-Pugh Class A and B): no initial dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Multicentric Castleman's disease, In patients known to be HIV-negative and human herpesvirus-8-negative

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe hypersensitivity to siltuximab or any of the product excipients

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- gastrointestinal (GI) perforation has been reported; use with caution in at risk patients and promptly evaluate if symptoms suggest GI perforation
  • Immunologic:
  • -- infections may occur; use not recommended if severe; monitoring recommended
  • Other:
  • -- infusion related reactions and hypersensitivity (eg, anaphylaxis) may occur; interrupt the infusion for mild to moderate infusion reactions and consider medications; depending on the severity of the reaction, may resume therapy with a reduced infusion rate after resolution of symptoms
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- use not recommended with live virus vaccines

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Edema (26% (all grades); 8% (grade 3 or 4))
  • Dermatologic:Lower respiratory tract infection (8%), Rash (28%), Upper respiratory infection (26% to 63%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypertriglyceridemia (8%), Hyperuricemia (11% (all grades); 2% (grade 3 or 4)), Weight increased (19% (all grades); 2% (grade 3 or 4))
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (8%), Diarrhea (32% (longterm exposure)), Pain, oropharyngeal (8%)
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia (9% (all grades); 4% (grade 3 or 4))
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (21% (longterm exposure))
  • Neurologic:Headache (8%)
  • Renal:Renal impairment (8%)
  • Respiratory:Rash (28% (all grades); 2% (grade 3 or 4))
  • Other:Fatigue (21% (longterm exposure)), Pain, In extremities (21% (longterm exposure))
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal perforation
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Infectious disease
  • Other:Infusion reaction (4.8%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Siltuximab is a human-mouse chimeric monoclonal antibody that binds soluble and membrane-bound interleukin-6 (IL-6). IL-6 can induce immunoglobulin secretion, and its overproduction is associated with systemic effects in patients with multicentric Castleman's disease.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • allow vials to come to room temperature over approximately 30 minutes
  • use a 21-gauge, 1.5-inch needle for preparation
  • reconstitute to 20 mg/mL with sterile water for injection (SWFI) by adding 5.2 mL to 100-mg vial or 20 mL to 400-mg vial
  • allow powder to completely dissolve without vigorous shaking or swirling; dissolution should occur within 60 minutes
  • add reconstituted solution to infusion bag within 2 hours and complete infusion within 4 hours of adding drug to infusion bag
  • 250-mL infusion bag must contain D5W and be made of polyolefin (PO) or polyvinyl chloride (PVC) with DEHP
  • slowly add reconstituted solution to D5W to create a final volume of 250 mL and gently invert bag to mix
  • infuse over 1 hour through PVC with DEHP- or polyurethane-lined administration sets containing a 0.2-micron inline filter
  • do not infuse in the same IV line with other agents
  • for mild to moderate infusion reactions, interrupt the infusion and restart at lower infusion rate; consider antihistamines, acetaminophen, and corticosteroids; discontinue if interventions are unsuccessful.
  • for severe infusion or allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, or cytokine release syndromes, permanently discontinue and do not restart treatment
  • discard any unused portion of the drug

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• tumor response and complete resolution or stabilization of multicentric Castleman's disease symptoms is indicative of efficacy
  • prior to the first dose: absolute neutrophil count is 1 x 10(9)/L or greater, the platelet count is 75 x 10(9)/L or greater, and the hemoglobin is less than 17 g/dL
  • prior to retreatment: absolute neutrophil count is 1 x 10(9)/L or greater, the platelet count is 50 x 10(9)/L or greater, and the hemoglobin is less than 17 g/dL
  • infection; during therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that live vaccines are not to be taken during therapy.
  • Counsel patients of childbearing to avoid pregnancy during treatment and for 3 months after discontinuation.
  • Side effects may include rash, itching, respiratory tract infection, edema, constipation, or headache.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of infection.
  • Tell patient to report symptoms of allergic reaction (eg, difficulty breathing, chest tightness, wheezing, dizziness) during administration.
  • Counsel patient to report any new or worsening medical conditions during therapy.
  • Advise patient that there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs.).
